question: 取る
sourceAnswer: to{} take/pick-up/grab/catch | pass/hand/give | get/obtain/acquire/win/receive/earn/take-(e.g.-a-vacation) | adopt-(a-method,-proposal,-etc.)/take-(a-measure,-attitude,-etc.)/choose | remove/get-rid-of/take-off | take-away/steal/rob | eat/have-(e.g.-lunch)/take-(e.g.-vitamins) | pick-(e.g.-flowers)/gather/extract-(e.g.-juice)/catch-(e.g.-fish) | take-up-(time,-space)/occupy/spare/set-aside | secure/reserve/save/put-aside/keep | take-(e.g.-a-joke)/interpret/understand/make-out/grasp | record/take-down | subscribe-to-(e.g.-a-newspaper)/take/buy/get | order/have-delivered | charge/fine/take-(tax) | take-(e.g.-a-wife)/take-on-(e.g.-an-apprentice)/adopt/accept | compete-(in-sumo,-cards,-etc.)/play
userAnswer: to{} take/pick-up/grab/get | reserve/secure | put-aside/keep | pass/hand | adopt | take-off
activeAnswer: to{} take/pick-up/grab/get | reserve/secure | put-aside/keep | pass/hand | adopt | take-off
userExplanation:
Take in a wide literal and metaphorical sense: 
adopt, pick, order, record, subscribe, charge, get, eat, [] time, [] responsibility...
sourceMnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>take</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to take something</vocabulary>.
sourceReadingMnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're the kind of person who likes <vocabulary>to take</vocabulary> things. "What things?" you ask. Little <reading>toe</reading>s (<ja>と</ja>). Because that isn't creepy.
